cab.content: 12SECRET.MINISTRY OF POOD.Report for Week ending Wednesday, October 30, 1918.The Food Council. Sir John Beale reported that he had discussed the feedingstuffs position at the Committee of Representatives and also with the Americanrepresentative. The American view was that there was no concentrated cake availablein U.S. for export owing to the partial failure of the cotton crop and the shortage oflinseed (of which U.S. was actually importing a quantity), and that ILK. shouldmake her own arrangements for getting the feeding stuffs required from othermarkets. It was decided to ask the Wheat Commission to report whether the millingprogramme could be modified so as to secure a greater output of offals, and in- whatway increased importation of cake and maize could be secured. The use of barleyfor feeding stuffs to be controlled through grist'mills was also considered.The shortage of meat was discussed. It was agreed that it was impossible toreduce the meat ration and that the ILK. could not expect any increased imports offrozen meat. It was considered essential to make the best possible use of the suppliesnow coming forward in view of probable demands on the part of recovered territoriesand of a further reduction in supplies after Christmas.A memorandum on malting barley in Ireland was considered. It appeared thatalthough the acreage under cultivation was in excess of previous years practically nobarley was coming to market either for millers or malsters. It was determined totake steps to encourage the marketing of barley, and to endeavour to control themovement of stock.Committee of Representatives. Meetings of the Committee of Representativesand of the Freight Committee have been held during the week. Special attention hasbeen given to the arrangements for conducting the provisioning of Serbia and therecovered territories of North France and Belgium, and further supplies to meetimmediate needs were sanctioned. Arrangements were made to supplement thesupplies of preserved meat and tish. for Italy which had got into arrear.Joint Finance Board.--The question of advances to Local "-Authorities for the-establishment of National Kitchens was discussed. It was decided to apply forTreasury sanction to take out leases for a term of 7 or 10 years for the purpose ofproviding premises, but that the Director of National Kitchens should be instructedto commit himself to the shortest term possible, and to obtain option of terminatingleases. - * - 1 v:- v v l,M ''In the matter of supplies obtainable in neutral or enemy countries after the war,the Wheat Commission advised the purchase of maize from the Argentine ; the SugarCommission reported that it was merely a question of tonnage as there were amplesupplies in Java awaiting shipment and. no need to make further advance purchases.The price of potatoes to bakers for the purpose of baking bread was discussed,and also the various anomalies that appeared in the bakers' accounts and in the priceof baking.Imports Board. M. Destombe's request for 10,000 tons of bacon and hams forrevictualling the French reconquered territory was discussed, and it was agreed tooffer 3,000 tons of hog products to the French Government for immediate delivery.It was not thought that existing stocks in the United Kingdom would admit furtheradvances,, but' the French Government were advised to consider the purchase ofAmerican products known to be available.It was agreed to apply for Treasury sanction to purchase the whole of theexportable surplus of A/ustralasian butter for the period of the war "and twelve monthsafterwards, r ': .A (33)6638-5 Pk 1 115 11/18 E & S APART I.-ACTION . TAKEN. 2It was agreed to submit an estimate of the proposed cost of purchasing tho wholeexportable sin-plus of butter and cheese from the Argentine, South Africa, andCanada.Supplies and Prices.Bacon. A census of curers in Great Britain shows that about 2,500 persons areengaged in curing, and require allocations of pigs. This number is considerablyabove what was expected, and includes many very small curers, whoso claims willraise administrative problems of considerable difficulty.Canned Salmon. In response to urgent requests made by the Representative ofPrisoners of War Committee for supplies of canned salmon to cover emergency, itwas decided to release 1,000,000 tins of 1 lb. each or their equivalent to the Com-mittee from the Ministry's stocks lying in the United Kingdom, although the holdingsof the Ministry on this side are extremely small. Details of brands and pi ices to besettled later.Cereals. On Wednesday, October 30, Mr. Paul gave evidence before the SelectCommittee on National Expenditure on the proposal to continue the subsidy in respectof potatoes used in the manufacture of bread, and pointed out that this would involvea saving in the amount of the bread subsidy.Citrous Fruits for Marmalade-making. Arrangements have been made with theBritish Purchasing Commission in Italy to buy the whole of the Sicilian crop ofbitter oranges which may not be required by the Italian Government for domesticconsumption (estimated from 2,000 to 4,000 tons) and 4,000 tons of sweet oranges ata price of 22 lire per box, also 15,000 tons of confectioners' lemons at 21 lire per boxof 88 lbs. net, all f.o.b. Sicilian ports.Purchases are also being made of 10,500 tons of bitter oranges and 2,000 tons ofsweet oranges in Spain. Under this scheme the Ministry will not finance thepurchases, which will be in the hands of Messrs. Boyd and Machin as last year.Shipments are expected to commence about the middle of November, and applicationsfor participation in allotments of fruit are now being received from the various jammanufacturers. The last day fixed for the receipt of applications is 1st November.Cocoa. The arrivals of cocoa are somewhat below those set out in ourprogramme, but the Ministry of Shipping have despatched urgent cables to theirrepresentatives on the West Coast of Africa to load larger quantities. It is hopedthat at least 7,000 tons may be shipped in November.The Cocoa Bean Shell (Requisition) Order, 1918, dated 29th October 1918,provides that the occupier of every factory or workshop in which raw cocoa beans areused shall place the whole of the output of cocoa bean shell at the disposal of theFood Controller on and after November 2nd. This control of the cocoa bean shellwill enable it to be distributed under the Feeding Stuffs Distribution Scheme.Coffee. The Admiralty Marshal has been asked to inscribe the purchasers' nameson the bonds issued by him. A list of these buyers will be kept and a copy will betransmitted to the Ministry of Food. By this means it is hoped that the speculationin the coffee market will partially, if not wholly, disappear. The Admiralty Marshalcontinues to supply the market with 5,000 bags of coffee per week.Dried Fruits. An additional purchase of 150 tons of Cape raisins has beeneffected. The S.S. " Nessian " has arrived at Liverpool with the first shipment of the2,000 tons of Californian sultanas. The remaining quantity is afloat and arrivals areexpected within the next ten days. A further shipment of Indian sultanas, part ofthis Ministry's purchase, have arrived during the week.Fish. Supplies of white fish have been moderate, and the demand good; herringsand kippers from the East Anglian ports have been heavy, some 2,500 tons arrivingduring the week ; also good supplies of Irish mackerel, with the result that sprats andsmall herrings have exceeded the demand, fair quantities finding their way to the fishmeal works.Transport and delivery on the whole has been good.Meat.-The measures which have been taken to restrict the number of cattlecoming into the markets have not yet limited the supply to the amount required. Inspite of this, some difficulty is being experienced in arranging for full supplies for theLondon area, owing partly to the lack of sufficient transport facilities and partly tothe lack of an adequate number of slaughtermen. Arrangements have been made to secure the temporary release of a number of slaughtermen from the army, but thishas not yet been done on a sufficient scale to cope with the situation. It may becomenecessary during the coming week to release some oi the home-killed meat recentlyfrozen and put into store, in order to furnish a supply for the London area. Nodifficulty need be experienced with regard to replacing such stocks, provided thatthe number of slaughtermen is increased. Priority is being given to the requirementsof the army, and this puts a somewhat heavy tax on London's slaughtering capacity,in which area the army demand is likely to amount to over 600 tons this week.The fact that the demand for civilian consumption is now being met almostentirely by home-grown meat permits the accumulation of reserve stocks of frozenmeat in store. These stocks are rapidly being restored to a more satisfactory level,and at the moment there is some pressure upon the storage accommodation. It is, ofcourse, desired to accumulate the largest reserve stocks possible in order to meet thesituation that will arise when home supplies fall off.Milk. Mr. Glynes received a deputation from the Bristol Food Control Oom-mittees from the West of England with regard to the winter milk prices. Thedeputation explained the views of their Committees that the price was excessive, andthat it would bear hardly on the poorer classes. Mr. Clynes explained at some lengththe reasons which had actuated him in fixing the price, and the necessity of ensuringa plentiful supply of milk during the winter months. He also explained that, in viewof the control over the wholesale distribution of milk which had now been takenby the Ministry, he had arranged for an inquiry to be made into the possibilities offixing a differential rate for various districts, and as soon as he received the result ofhis investigation he would consider whether there was any possibility of reducing theprice. He also called attention to the special facilities which existed for providingmilk at a reduced cost.The Consumers' Council at their meeting on Wednesday, October 30, consideredthe financial arrangements necessary to be made if Mr. Butler, of the United Dairies,Ltd., became the servant of the Department. The discussion was adjourned untilnext week.Oils and Fats. The Food Controller has decided to reduce the price of oil andfat compound from 150s. per cwt. to 140s. per cwt. to the consumer as fromNovember 17th.Oranges and Lemons. - -Meetings with the Trade have been held with a view tofixing the price of sweet oranges and lemons. Under this Order oranges will be soldby retail at lOd. per lb. The schedule price for lemons is not yet completed. TheOrder, with the exception of the Lemon Schedule, has gone forward to the OrdersCommittee, and it is hoped will be signed on Monday, November 4th.Potatoes.-.-The Food Controller will, on November 1st, take control of the wholepotato crop of England and Wales.The prices to be paid to the growers have been fixed by a Commission appointedby the Food Controller and the President of the Board of Agriculture jointly. Thereport of this Commission prescribed the different growers' prices for each areaaccording to the yield, quality, and cost of production of the crop, and are for twogrades of potatoes.While the prices for producers will vary in different areas, the price to the publicfor the same grade of potato will be uniform throughout England and Wales. Untilthe end of December Grade 1 potato will be retailed at a uniform price of l\d. per lb.,and Grade 2 at a uniform price of Id. per lb.For purposes of administration England and Wales have been divided into11 deficit zones, which will need, at some time or other during the year, to importpotatoes from elsewhere, and 12 surplus zones, which will export potatoes. In eachsurplus zone is a Zonal Committee under a Zonal Chairman responsible for organisingthe collection of potatoes for export to other areas. In each deficit zone is a PotatoControl Committee under the Chairmanship of the Food Commissioner. Thesecommittees will he empowered to issue directions relating to the, collection anddisposal of potatoes. Subject to any restrictions imposed by the Potato ControlCommittee, or the Zonal Committee, growers will be permitted to sell potatoes to anyregistered wholesale dealer in their zone, but may not sell to anyone else except underlicence, to be obtained from the Food Commissioner of their area. Leaflets for theguidance of growers, registered wholesale dealers, and retail dealers in potatoes, havebeen issued. These arrangements relate only to ware potatoes. Growers will be free to sellundersized potatoes subject to a maximum price of 3Z. 10s. per ton free on rail.Undersized potatoes, for which a market cannot be found in the ordinary way, will betaken over by the Ministry of Food at the fixed price of 3Z. per ton prescribed by theJoint Commission. Seed potatoes will be dealt with separately.Poultry. By an Order dated 29th October 1918, the maximum price is increasedfor cockerels between 6 ozs. and 1 lb. in weight. The object is to promote hatching,and, by encouraging the killing of cockerels, to save feeding stuffs for laying birds.Pulping Stations. The only fruit pulping which has been done this summeris at Totnes and Bridgwater. At Totnes about 250 tons of blackberries have beenlaid down and at Bridgwater 20 tons. The latter station was opened for a shortperiod on account of the railway strike. Sloes are now being pulped at Totnes stationand it is anticipated that we shall secure about 50 tons of this fruit. The followingstations are being prepared for handling oranges and lemons : Maidstone, Totnes,Bridgwater, Cheltenham, Sittingbourne, Faversham, Doncaster, Evesham (ValleyWorks), Paddock Wood.Tea. 3,000,000 lbs. of tea have been purchased in China, and arrangementsmade to obtain the necessary tonnage.'; Rationing. ,As a result of several conferences held with the Admiralty, War Office,and Air Ministry representatives, arrangements have practically been completedfor the issue of ration documents to soldiers reverting to civilian life on generaldemobilisation. On being sent home from a dispersal station a demobilised soldierwill receive a " Demobilisation Ration Book," containing coupons for a fortnight.This book will be exchangeable for a civilian ration book on presentation at a FoodOffice.The Demobilisation Ration Books are ready to be sent to press as soon as theWar Office have agreed to the proposal that they should contain meat coupons on thecivilian ration scale. The War Office agreement to this proposal is expected within afew days. Sufficient supplies of the books to meet the initial demand on demobilisationwillbe printed immediately.The Ministry are in communication with the Admiralty, War Office, and AirMinistry, with a view to taking over surplus army and navy stores which may bereleased for the use of the civilian population after demobilisation.Jam Rationing. The necessary arrangements for distribution under the JamRationing Scheme which comes into force on 3rd November are being proceededwith. Various meetings of the Jam Advisory Committee and representatives of thewholesale and retail trades have been held to discuss the scheme.A good deal of time has been occupied in the registration of wholesale dealers.This is now nearly complete, the total number of licences issued up to the presentbeing 856.Manufacturers who were restricted by the Jam Manufacturers' (Restriction)Order, 1918, from sending out beyond specified quantities before 31st October have' been notified that they are now at liberty to send out further quantities conditionalon their obtaining an undertaking in writing from the various customers that the jamwill not be offered for sale, Or otherwise disposed of, before the 3rd of November.: A second meeting took place at Grosvenor House oh the 23rd of October, betweenthe Consumers' Counciland the Food Commissioners, at which the proposals for thedistribution of cheese were discussed. A concensus of opinion was expressed infavour^ of placing consignments of cheese in the hands of the Commissioners, forallocation to areas to meet special requirements.Divisional Reports.The Commissioner for the North-west Division reports that the supplementaryration of cheese issued to heavy workers, and increased supplies to wholesalers lastmonth, have materially decreased the number of complaints.The Commissioner for'the Home Counties calls attention to the difficulties in therural areas caused by the high price of clothing. Parents declare that the present 52C9price and inferior quality of boots will make it impossible to send their childrento school during the winter. He urges the need of providing mid-day meals at theschools, which, in his opinion, would require to be State-aided, more especially in thesmaller country districts. The provision of transport for fuel for the cottage popula-tion is also mentioned as becoming a serious problem.In the West of Scotland, as a result of the shortage of feeding stuffs, largequantities of game and poultry are coming into the market, and being sold consider-ably under controlled prices. Arrangements have therefore been made locally withthe cold storage authorities to allow surplus birds to be put in store for use later.This measure should improve competition in the market. Owing to the very stormyweather in the past fortnight, fish supplies in this,a-rea have been very short. Herringfishermen were not able to go out to the fishing grounds, and in consequence all fishwere being sold at maximum prices.Enforcement of Orders.The total number of prosecutions for the past week is 894, of which 850 resultedin convictions.The Divisions mainly affected were as follows : Division. Prosecutions. Convictions.North-west - 174 98 per cent.Home Counties - - 105 97North - - 69 100 ,,South-west - 52 90 ,,London - - 51 96 ,,The most noticeable contribution to the week's prosecutions is a series of 80summonses against various offenders under the Pigs (Prices) Order at Blackpool.This was the result of a raid carried out by the police. The fines total 6601.,averaging 8Z. 5s. each.PART II.-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION.Imports.Imports of the principal food-stuffs in the week ended 26th October (196,200 tons)again show an increase over those of the preceding week (192,700 tons) and asubstantial excess beyond those of the corresponding week of last year (141,400 tons);they are also above the average of the first 43 weeks of the calendar year 1918(181,200 tons), though they are still below the average of the corresponding weeks ofthe year 1917 (229,300 tons),, (Table A). For the first time during the current cerealyear the total imports (1,441,100 tons) exceed those of, the corresponding period oflast year (1,400,800 tons).Compared with the week ended 19th October there has been an improved importof sugar (17,000 1 tons increase), and of bacon, lard, butter, cheese, condensedmilk, and cocoa, though the imports of bacon (7,800 tons), and in a less degreethose of cheese (2,400 tons) are still insufficient to meet the weekly consumption.There was a small. import of tea after the abnormally high import of the previousweek, and no coffee. As regards cereals, wheat and -flour as grain (112,800 tons)showed the highest weekly import during the current cereal year, but other cereals(19,200 tons) were below the average; very little barley (180 tons); and no ricearrived. 6The total imports for the first eight weeks of the cereal years 1917-18 and1918-19 are compared in the following table: Total Imports in the first 8 weeks of cereal year. 1917. 1918. The continued increase in. consumption of bread and flourwas pointed out in last week's Report. It will be seen from Table G that theincrease was general throughout the country but was greater in London and the largetowns than in the smaller towns and rural districts where, however, the increase inconsumption had already reached a high level.A comparison with the corresponding period of last year shows that the increaseis made up of a heavy increase in the amount of flour used in bread and a reductionin the amount sold as flour an indication of the decreased use of flour for homebaking. The figures show that the fall has been greatest in Scotland and in theNorth of England.In view of the decision of the Ministry to require, by order, the use of potatoes inbread to the extent of 20 lbs. of potatoes to every 280 lbs. of flour, the present extentto which potatoes are so used is of special interest. The returns show that only onebaker out of 23 uses potatoes in the manufacture of bread, and that only 1 lb. ofpotatoes is used to every 280 lbs. of flour. The maximum use recorded sinceFebruary 1918 was in June, when old crop potatoes were available, but even thenonly 3^ lbs. of potatoes were used to every 280 lbs. of flour.Meat. The number of cattle and sheep accepted for slaughter in Great Britainduring the week ended 19th October showed little change on the preceding week, andthe total supply of butchers' meat, inclusive of 900 tons refrigerated meat, is estimatedat 16,100 tons. Consumption is thus approximating more closely to the rationquantity. The congestion of live stock at the markets continues; the army autho-rities are not yet taking up the numbers agreed upon, but, on the other hand, it ishoped that arrangements recently made as to freezing and storing and the higherscale of winter prices now offered to farmers will go far towards conserving supplies.Fish.
